description: From Middle English thiggen, from Old English þiċġan (“to take, receive, accept; ingest; eat or drink, consume, partake of”), from Proto-Germanic *þigjaną (“to accept, receive, beg”), from Proto-Indo-European *tek- (“to receive”).
Cognate with Middle High German digen (“to beg, implore, beseech”), German digen (“to beg, beseech, take, get”), Swedish tigga (“to beg, mooch”), Icelandic þiggja (“to get, receive, accept”).

verbs.description: thig (third-person singular simple present thigs, present participle thigging, simple past and past participle thigged)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To solicit, usually by begging; ask as alms; beg.
(obsolete, intransitive) To profit by or live on the gifts of others.
(obsolete, transitive, intransitive, Scotland) To crave; seek (a favour).
